angry.title: Anger / Irritability
angry.summary: Anger can come from stress, unmet needs, or physical discomfort. Short grounding and breathing practices help calm the nervous system and protect facial tension from lasting (jaw/forehead) strain.
tips: Pause and breathe: try 4-4-4 breathing (inhale 4s, hold 4s, exhale 4s) for 1–2 minutes.
Do a quick facial release: massage jaw and temples with light circular motions for 30–60 seconds.
Take a 5–10 minute walk outside to change perspective and reduce built-up tension.
Use grounded posture: sit/stand with shoulders relaxed and chin level to reduce facial clenching.
Write one short sentence about what’s bothering you — externalizing reduces rumination.

disgust.title: Disgust / Aversion
disgust.summary: Disgust is a protective emotion but can cause tightened facial expressions and avoidance. Gentle exposure and sensory grounding reduce reactivity and help keep facial muscles relaxed.
tips: Name the sensation aloud (e.g., “That feels uncomfortable”) to reduce its intensity.
Try a 30-second sensory reset: hold a cool glass of water and focus on the feeling.
Soften your face: deliberately relax mouth, forehead and jaw for 20 seconds.
Limit immediate avoidance—step back briefly, breathe, then decide the next action.
If triggered by smell/food, rinse mouth and change environment to a neutral scent.

fear.title: Fear / Anxiety
fear.summary: Fear provokes alertness and facial tension (wide eyes, furrowed brow). Short co-regulation strategies and slow breathing help lower adrenaline and protect eye strain and tense expressions.
tips: Slow diaphragmatic breathing: 4–6 slow breaths per minute for two minutes.
Ground with senses: list 5 things you see, 4 you can touch, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste.
Lower screen brightness and take soft-focus breaks to avoid wide-eyed strain.
Try progressive muscle relaxation for face: tense 3s, release 7s, focusing on jaw/forehead.
If it's anticipatory fear, write the worst-case plan + one small next step to regain control.

happy.title: Happiness / Joy
happy.summary: Happiness shows as relaxed, uplifting facial expressions. Reinforce healthy habits that keep your face and skin glowing and prevent fatigue after emotional highs.
tips: Smile gently for 20 seconds (even a deliberate smile can boost mood) and breathe slowly.
Hydrate and rest—positive emotion can still tax energy; aim for a brief 10–15 minute rest after big events.
Protect skin from excess sun or sweat after outdoor celebration—wash face and apply sunscreen.
Capture the moment: take one photo or write a short gratitude note to reinforce positive memory.
Keep regular sleep and meal patterns to sustain mood and maintain healthy facial appearance.

sad.title: Sadness / Low mood
sad.summary: Sadness often relaxes facial muscles and can lead to fatigue or puffy eyes. Small behavioral activations and self-care preserve facial health and help mood recover.
tips: Allow a short, intentional time to feel (5–15 minutes) then do one small activity (walk, call a friend).
Apply cold/warm compress to the face or eyes for 5–10 minutes to reduce puffiness and refresh.
Practice light movement (stretching or a 10-minute walk) to increase circulation and energy.
Use gentle facial massage (cheeks, under-eyes) to relieve stagnation and improve circulation.
Keep a hydration and sleep checkpoint: drink a glass of water and plan a short, consistent bedtime.

surprise.title: Surprise / Startle
surprise.summary: Surprise is brief and sharp — it can cause sudden facial tension (raised brows, widened eyes). Quick grounding and softening reduce strain and prevent lasting tension.
tips: Take three slow, full breaths to reset after the startle.
Blink slowly several times and soften your gaze to relax eye muscles.
Drop shoulders and loosen the jaw with gentle circular movements for 20–30 seconds.
If heart rate feels high, place one hand on your chest and breathe slowly until steadier.
Reflect briefly on what surprised you and whether action is needed before reacting.

neutral.title: Neutral / Baseline
neutral.summary: Neutral is a stable baseline. Maintain simple daily routines that protect facial relaxation, eye comfort, and skin micro-stress to keep your face well over time.
tips: Follow the 20-20-20 rule during screen work to avoid eye strain (every 20 min look 20 ft for 20 s).
Do a 60-second micro-break every hour: stand, roll shoulders, soften jaw and forehead.
Hydrate consistently and keep an even sleep schedule to prevent puffiness and fatigue.
Practice a short daily face-care ritual: gentle cleansing and light massage to improve circulation.
When stressed rises, use a 2-minute breathing or grounding exercise to preserve neutral expression.
